sect1.title: Summary
sect1.para: Throughout this chapter, we have described the unique considerations, experiences, and needs of older adults that may be relevant to the conducting of a mental health diagnostic interview. Critical components include engaging in multimethod assessment, considering medical and cognitive contexts, and bearing in mind diversity and cultural contexts in older adults, specifically the presence of and potential impact of ageism. Given the heightened likelihood of chronic medical issues in older adults, clinicians should be prepared to review medical information, including current medication use, and consult and collaborate with medical providers when appropriate consent is obtained. Recommendations may similarly move beyond the psychological domain and include guidance for further consultation with a medical provider (e. g., neurologists). Overall, quality, informed diagnostic interviewing with older adults involves holding space for the potential ways in which the circumstances of older adults may differ from other lifespan periods while also not making age-related assumptions that overlook individual difference or perpetuate bias. Clinicians must acknowledge and promote the protective factors (e. g., social supports, meaningful activities, positive self-concept) that may buoy an older adult through challenging times as well as recognize the risk factors that may contribute to an older adult experiencing a mental disorder.
